status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent. National Grid is installing a new main on your street. The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. Even though the contactor will installing a new main usually for hundreds of feet and in some cases the entire street, we have told the contractor to only post where he will be for the next few days. This will allow more parking on the street. We spoke to the crew and told them they have to follow this requirement . They apologized and said they would comply going forward.  The sign is valid, in fact it tells you who the permiteee is and the contractor doing the work. We apologize for the inconvenience this necessary work will cause. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. As you aware of. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. We will tell Feeney they can only park the registered  equipment when they leave the job at the end of their shifts .. this should only be the back hoe. We apologize for the parking inconvenience. The CIU Inspector for your neighborhood is Sean Smolinsky.  Sean can be reached at  781-858-7546. You can call Mal anytime regarding issues on the street that need immediate attention. Again the City apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. NSTAR had received an Occupancy Permit (OCCU-758529) from BTD to work in the area. Also keep in mind that whenever an electrical company is doing work in that area and there is a scheduled power outage for the Verizon building. As a result, Verizon had to use their generator to keep their central office equipment and other system running in this part of the city.   Verizon did apologize for the inconvenience they might have caused the neighbors, but stated that there was no other ways to keep their equipment running during planned power outage. Whenever there is a power outage, they will need to run the generator.  I hope you find this information helpful. . Sincerely,. . Lugardy Raymond.

description:
As a mother living in Allston, I'm so saddened and angry at the choice of "art" that was chosen for our neighborhood. My daughters noticed this on the way to school today. This depicts woman and girls so poorly. (That's the nicest way I can say it) I, along with other moms in the neighborhood are appalled. We are raising our girls to be strong, independent, respected, and to know they can do anything in this world. To see that this graffiti art was approved by the city is telling the girls of our community a very different thing. Sad. Our neighborhood is already overrun by graffiti and rats. Let's try some real art for a change. Something that shows Allston has families that contribute to the city. 
Thank you,
 Rochelle, Alyssa and Maia Dunne
42 Pratt Street 
Allston

description: At 6:50 a.m. a street sweeper pulled the wrong way onto Beech St. I was coming down Beech St with another driver behind me towards West Roxbury Parkway. Although he was going the wrong way up a one way street, he refused to back up or pull over to let us by. He then leaned out his window and started yelling obscenities at me while I was driving my young daughter to school. He leaned out of the window and gave me the middle finger. He refused to move so the car behind me had to back up Beach Street and that I had to back up Beach Street and go all the way around on to Belgrade Avenue which was not our destination. This behavior is absolutely unacceptable and it's unclear to me why he went up the wrong way street at a very busy time in the morning in the first place. I would like to hear what is being done to make sure this does not happen again.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing an old  gas main on Centre St. In addition to replacing a the old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. As far as the posting issues you are totally correct. The permit is expired.. they are currently in the process of extending. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent. On streets where there are pavement markings (crosswalks double yellows, skip lines, left turn only etc)  have either faded or been paved over or impacted by utility work the proper way to restore pavement markings is with thermal plastic. Its a public safety issue to get the pavement markings restored as soon as possible. Because many of the streets are main arterials or feeders streets work during the day is difficult resulting in the work being done at night. . All utility companies and private contractors working in the City of Boston are required to order Police details. A Police detail was ordered for this job. Sometimes the details are not filled. I spoke to the City Engineers and asked that they leaflett streets to be impacted by pavement marking work. The City apologizes for the inconvenience this work has caused. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. All  utility companies or private contractors working in the City of Boston are required to have Police details. A Police detail was called for this job. Sometimes, the details are not filled, or a Police officer is up the street,. Unfortunately in this case, the detail was not filled. The PWD has reached out to the Boston Police about the need to fill the detail requests. The City apologizes for the inconvenience for this necessary work. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

description:
CENTRAL SQUARE TRAFFIC!!

The traffic in East Boston in the morning rush hour is out of control. The traffic lights are not synced, and the merge lanes to get into the Sumner tunnel back up all the way down Meridian St, sometimes taking 30 minutes to go less than a half mile. Something needs to be done about this!! We need another lane into the tunnel that alleviates the traffic backing all the way up into East Boston. What if there is a medical emergency?! There is absolutely no where for an ambulance to go, let alone other first responder vehicles. This traffic pattern/central square design is not safe for the residents of East Boston!!
